But their new show isn't likely to win many converts to the cause (2:30). Newhouse, Lincoln Center, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    * 'HURLYBURLY' If you are going to inhabit a wasteland, you might as well be thoroughly wasted. That seems to be the first rule of survival for the characters who have been brought so vibrantly and unforgivingly to life in this smashing revival of David Rabe's 1984 play. But thanks to a terrific cast, theatergoers are likely to experience a heady buzz of excitement and clarity that any of the desperate characters onstage would kill for (3:15). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    'LAZER VAUDEVILLE' If this isn't an ancient showbiz rule, it ought to be: things will look a lot more impressive if they are done in the dark with a heavy dose of fluorescence. That seems to be the guiding principle behind this hodgepodge of juggling, rope twirling and such, delivered wordlessly by the cast (1:30). Houseman, 450 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212)239-6200. Closing tomorrow at the Houseman. Reopening June 9 at the Lambs Theater, 130 West 44th Street. (Neil Genzlinger)    'THE MAIDS' It is no small feat to find the chill in Jean Genet's 1947 play about two maids who fantasize about killing their boss, but Jean Cocteau Repertory manages it. Credit an eye-opening performance by Amanda Jones as Solange, the dominant of the two maids (2:00). Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery, at Bond and East Second Streets, (212)279-4200. (Genzlinger)    'NINE PARTS OF DESIRE' The voices are a study in contrasts: vivid and subdued, sophisticated and naive, seductive and standoffish. But they cohere to form a powerful collective portrait of suffering and endurance in Heather Raffo's impassioned theatrical documentary about the lives of contemporary Iraqi women (1:25). Manhattan Ensemble Theater, 55 Mercer Street, at Broome Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    * 'ORSON'S SHADOW' Austin Pendleton's play, about a 1960 production of Ionesco's ''Rhinoceros'' directed by Orson Welles and starring Laurence Olivier, is a sharp-witted but tender-hearted backstage comedy about the thin skins, inflamed nerves and rampaging egos that are the customary side effects when sensitivity meets success (2:00). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    * 'THE PASSION OF THE CRAWFORD' For his slight but still tasty new show, John Epperson has decided to allow his voiceless alter ego, Lypsinka, to commune intimately and at length with one of her spiritual forebears, Joan Crawford. The centerpiece is a pointed but never vicious re-creation, or rather an interpretation, of a live interview Crawford gave at Town Hall in 1973 (1:30). Zipper, 336 West 37th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    'THE PEOPLE NEXT DOOR' Henry Adam's play starts out as a humorous, trenchant fable on how fear of terrorism can distort individual lives, not to say nations, but something mysterious happens after intermission: it mutates into a sitcom. The actors Ronny Jhutti and Mark McDonnell are very much worth watching, though. Part of Brits Off Broadway (2:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212)279-4200. (Andrea Stevens)    'A PICASSO' Jeffrey Hatcher's play is a formulaic two-hander set in occupied Paris in 1941. Pablo Picasso (Dennis Boutsikaris) is brought in for interrogation by the severe Miss Fischer (Jill Eikenberry), who works for the German cultural ministry (1:10). City Center Stage II, 131 West 55th Street, (212)581-1212. (Isherwood)    'SCORE' The subject of this one-man show is Leonard Bernstein and music, and the performer Tom Nelis, and the director, Anne Bogart, ''get'' Lenny -- now brilliant, now flamboyant, now superficial, now physically responding to recorded music (1:30). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, (212) 239-6200. (Anne Midgette)    * 'SHOCKHEADED PETER' A gorgeous ''nasty picture book'' of a musical, in which badly behaved Victorian tots come to ghastly ends. Inspired by Heinrich Hoffmann's droll collection of grisly bedtime stories, ''Shockheaded Peter'' is both the silliest and most sinister show in town. It is also one of the smartest (1:40). Little Shubert Theater, 422 West 42nd Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'SLAVA'S SNOWSHOW' A giggle of clowns chosen by the Russian master Slava Polunin is stirring up laughter and enjoyment. A show that touches the heart as well as tickles the funnybone (1:30). Union Square, 100 East 17th Street, (212)307-4100 . (Lawrence Van Gelder)    * 'THOM PAIN (BASED ON NOTHING)' Is there such a thing as stand-up existentialism? If not, Will Eno has just invented it. Stand-up-style comic riffs and deadpan hipster banter keep interrupting the corrosively bleak narrative. Mr. Eno is a Samuel Beckett for the Jon Stewart generation (1:10). DR2 Theater, 103 East 15th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    'WOMAN BEFORE A GLASS' Peggy Guggenheim, doyenne of the 20th-century art world, becomes the latest public figure to be exhumed onstage in this one-woman show starring the formidable Mercedes Ruehl. Written by Lanie Robertson, the play is gaudy and moderately fun (1:40). Promenade, Broadway at 76th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)    Off Off Broadway    'LES BELLES SOEURS' There is a good John Waters movie hiding inside Michael Tremblay's all-woman play. This likable comedy about a New England woman who wins a million trading stamps wants to be a farce but is just a collection of observations searching for a shape (1:30). Center Stage NY, 48 West 21st Street, (212)330-8650, closing at Center Stage on Sunday. The production moves to the Kraine Theater, 85 East Fourth Street, East Village for performances on May 21 and 22. (Anita Gates)    'CHANTECLER' A version of Edmond Rostand's fable about a rooster and his role in the cosmos, looks like a family show and bills itself as a family show, but it's pitched way over the heads of the age group that would most enjoy its colorful costumes. But Cory Einbinder, the director, manages to make a smattering of scenes memorable: a parade of mutant roosters; a ridiculous trio of toads (2:20). Teatro La Tea, at Clemente Soto Valez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, second floor, (212)353-3101. (Genzlinger)    'THE PURSUIT OF PERSEPHONE' A musical inspired by F. Scott Fitzgerald's college romance with Ginevra King, jams 26 songs into two and a half hours -- which feels even longer. The evening's most entertaining moments are the drag routines by the Triangle Club, a fraternity to which Fitzgerald belonged when he was at Princeton (2:30). Prospect Theater Company, at the Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, (212)352-3101. (Phoebe Hoban)    'PLANET BANANA' If you think women's gymnastics would be more interesting if performed in outfits from the Victoria's Secret catalog, then ''Planet Banana'' is the place for you. Featuring incongruous stunts, moderately difficult circus routines and a sketchy searching-for-love story, the show is as enjoyable as it is raucous (1:25). Ars Nova, 511 West 54th Street, (212)868-4444. (Genzlinger)    Long-Running Shows    'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden, 252 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh -- sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street , (212)307-4747. (Brantley)    'BLUE MAN GROUP' Conceptual art as family entertainment (1:45). Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street, (212)254-4370. (Brantley)    'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador, 219 West 49th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'MOVIN' OUT' The miracle dance musical that makes Billy Joel cool (2:00). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    'NAKED BOYS SINGING' That's who they are. That's what they do (1:05). Julia Miles Theater, 414 West 55th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Gates)    'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'THE PRODUCERS' The ne plus ultra of showbiz scams (2:45). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)    'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    'STOMP' And the beat goes on (and on), with percussion unlimited (1:30). Orpheum Theater, Second Avenue at Eighth Street, (212)477-2477. (Brantley)    'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin, 222 West 51st Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)    Last Chance    'ABSOLUTELY FASCINATING' Cheers to the British cabaret trio that calls itself Fascinating Aida. These women revel in the here and now. They are bawdy and political; loopy (in that crisp English way) and whimsical (2:00). Kirk Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, (212)279-4200, closing on Sunday. ( Margo Jefferson)    'PERSEUS' Performed in ancient Greek, ''Perseus'' tells the story of the son of Zeus who slew the serpent-headed Medusa and saved Andromeda from a sea monster. The production has the flamboyant pageantry and occasional ridiculousness of a low rent runway show (1:40). La MaMa Annex, 66 East Fourth Street, (212)475-7710, closing on Sunday. (Jason Zinoman)    'PRIVILEGE' Paul Weitz's delicate if uneven comedy examines the collateral damage sustained by the family of a disgraced titan of Wall Street. Humanizing a world normally glimpsed only it tabloid flashes, the play is also, and most memorably, a touching hymn to the sustaining bonds of fraternal affection. Conor Donovan and Harry Zittel are terrific as the sons of the fallen businessman (2:00). Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, (212)246-4422, closing on Wednesday. (Isherwood)    'SISTERS, SUCH DEVOTED SISTERS' Mixing fact and fiction as the transvestite Bernice Hindley, the actor Russell Barr tells a dark and caustic tale of life on the underside in Edinburgh. He was funniest, though, when riffing on a collection of eccentrics from Bernice's -- and presumably his own -- family. Part of Brits Off Broadway (1:00). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212)279-4200, closing on Sunday. (Stevens)    'THE THREE MUSKETEERS' A lot of story and actors have been crammed into this musical version. Unfortunately, that seems to have left little room for other crucial ingredients, like panache (2:30). Wings, 154 Christopher Street, (212)627-2961, closing tomorrow. (Genzlinger)    * 'TWELVE ANGRY MEN' This stage adaptation of Reginald Rose's celebrated television drama from 1954 (made into a film in 1957) suggests that sometimes the best way to present a fossil is just to polish it up and put it on display without disguise, annotation or apology. Even those who like their theater hip and cerebral might want to lower their eyebrows for this production. (1:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212)719-1300, closing on Sunday. (Brantley)    Movies    Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.    'A LOT LIKE LOVE' (PG-13, 107 minutes). A film that isn't half bad and every so often is pretty good, filled with real sentiment, worked-through performances and a story textured enough to sometimes feel a lot like life. (Manohla Dargis)    'THE AMITYVILLE HORROR' (R, 89 minutes). Low-key creepy rather than outright scary, this remake of the soporific 1979 horror flick marks a modest improvement on the original. But this time don't get attached to the family dog. (Dargis)    'BORN INTO BROTHELS' (not rated, 85 minutes, in Bengali). A lovely documentary about children of prostitutes in Calcutta. (A.O. Scott)    * 'THE BEST OF YOUTH' (not rated, 6 hours and 23 minutes, shown in two parts; in Italian). Marco Tullio Giordana's six-hour journey through recent Italian history is nothing less than a masterpiece, combining epic sweep with precise, heart-rending intimacy. (Scott)    'BROTHERS' (R, 113 minutes, in Danish). This gripping psychological drama is Susanne Bier's second film to examine events worthy of Greek tragedy through a contemporary therapeutic lens; wartime trauma and sibling rivalry collide. (Stephen Holden)    'CRASH' (R, 107 minutes). A gaggle of Los Angeles residents from various economic and ethnic backgrounds collide, sometimes literally, in the course of an extremely hectic 36-hour period. Well-intentioned, impressively acted, but ultimately a speechy, ponderous melodrama of liberal superstition masquerading as realism. (Scott)    'DOUBLE DARE' (not rated, 81 minutes). This new documentary about (stunt) women who like to roll cars, throw punches and jump from gaspingly tall heights is another reminder of how tough it is for the second sex to make it in Hollywood. (Dargis)    * 'ENRON: THE SMARTEST GUYS IN THE ROOM' (not rated, 110 minutes). This sober, informative chronicle of the biggest business scandal of the decade is almost indecently entertaining, in part because it offers some of the most satisfying movie villains in quite some time. Recommended for everyone except those likely to be in the Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling jury pools. (Scott)    * 'FEVER PITCH' (PG-13, 98 minutes). To watch this new, thoroughly winning if not especially good romantic comedy is to appreciate, yet again, that the great loves of our lives are rarely perfect. (Dargis)    * 'FUNNY HA HA' (not rated, 89 minutes). Twenty-somethings looking for love, direction and fulfilling work -- this smart, cheaply made first feature is low-key, note-perfect and sneakily artful. (Scott)    'THE GIRL FROM MONDAY' (not rated, 84 minutes). Like so many science fiction fantasies, this deadpan comedy, which is ''Brave New World'' Lite, begins with a witty premise, then stumbles all over itself trying to tell a coherent, original story. (Holden)    * 'THE HITCHHIKER'S GUIDE TO THE GALAXY' (PG, 103 minutes). In this hugely likable, long-awaited film of Douglas Adams's beloved book, the world comes to an end not just with a bang, but also with something of a shrug. Nicely directed with heart and sincerity by the newcomer Garth Jennings, the film features Martin Freeman, a sensational Sam Rockwell and some gloriously singing dolphins. (Dargis)    * 'THE HOLY GIRL' (not rated, 106 minutes; in Spanish). The Argentine director Lucrecia Martel's second feature is an oblique, feverish exploration of religious ecstasy and adolescent sexuality. Hard to classify, other than as a miraculous piece of filmmaking. (Scott)    'HOUSE OF D' (PG-13, 97 minutes). Robin Williams plays a wise and kindly mentally retarded janitor. Enough said. (Scott)    'HOUSE OF WAX' (R, 105 minutes). Not the depilatory sequel to ''Beauty Shop,'' but rather a remake of the 1953 Vincent Price creepshow, with Paris Hilton, Elisha Cuthbert and a bunch of guys menaced by maniacs in the Louisiana backwoods. Grisly and slow. (Scott)    'THE INTERPRETER' (PG-13, 123 minutes). A political thriller, both apolitical and unthrilling, notable for two accomplishments: turning the United Nations into a movie set, and, even more remarkably, giving Nicole Kidman the opportunity to embody the suffering of Africans everywhere. (Scott)    'JIMINY GLICK IN LALAWOOD' (R, 90 minutes). This frantic comic hodgepodge built around Martin Short's popular Comedy Central character is an intermittently funny free-for-all that suffers from attention deficit disorder. (Holden)    'KINGDOM OF HEAVEN' (R, 145 minutes). A plaintive period epic from Ridley Scott, starring Orlando Bloom, about the bloody orgies of piety known as the Crusades. The film proves yet again that it takes an actor as self-serious as Russell Crowe to carry the weight of Mr. Scott's ambitions; it also takes a story Mr. Scott himself can really believe in for the filmmaker to do the same. (Dargis)    'KING'S RANSOM' (PG-13, 97 minutes). The cinematic equivalent of trampled chewing gum on a subway platform. (Holden)    'KUNG FU HUSTLE' (R, 95 minutes, in Mandarin and Cantonese). This kinetic, exhausting, relentlessly entertaining film throws scraps of a half-century of international pop culture into a fast-whirling blender. (Scott)    'LADIES IN LAVENDER' (PG-13, 104 minutes). Two Dames of the British empire (Judi Dench and Maggie Smith) inhabit spinster sisters in Cornwall who nurse a handsome Polish violinist back to health in 1936. Amiably bogus. (Holden)    * 'LOOK AT ME' (PG-13, 110 minutes; in French). A delicious comedy, as tart as it is sweet, of ambition, miscommunication and egoism. Set in a Paris that seems to be populated entirely by artists and writers, the film affectionately tweaks the bad manners and complacency of France's intellectual elite. (Scott)    'MELINDA AND MELINDA' (PG-13, 99 minutes). The same story, more or less, told two different ways -- as serious drama and as comedy. Though Woody Allen's drama lacks emotional intensity and the comedy lacks funny jokes, the director interweaves them deftly enough. (Scott)    * 'MILLIONS' (PG, 97 minutes). Given the gaudy violence that frequently moves Danny Boyle's stories forward and keeps them jumping, it may come as something of a surprise that he has directed a heartfelt, emotionally delicate children's movie about life and death and all the parts in between. (Dargis)    'MISS CONGENIALITY 2: ARMED AND FABULOUS' (PG-13, 100 minutes). Wading through this junky sequel to her genial goofball hit ''Miss Congeniality,'' Sandra Bullock looks as if she would rather be shoveling pig waste, though of course in some respects that is exactly what she's doing. (Dargis)    * 'MYSTERIOUS SKIN' (not rated, 99 minutes). Gregg Araki, one-time bad-boy of the New Queer Cinema, has made a heartbreaking and surpassingly beautiful film out of Scott Heim's clear-eyed novel about two Kansas boys dealing with the consequences of their sexual abuse by a little league coach. Superb performances, especially Joseph Gordon-Levitt. (Scott)    'OLDBOY' (R, 118 minutes; in Korean). The latest in dubious pulp-fiction cool, ''Oldboy'' centers on a seemingly ordinary businessman, Dae-su (the terrific Choi Min-sik), who, after being mysteriously imprisoned, goes on an exhausting rampage, seeking answers and all manner of bloody revenge. (Dargis)    'PALINDROMES' (not rated, 100 minutes). The same backward and forward: dud. (Scott)    'ROBOTS' (PG, 89 minutes). This computer-animated film's setting, a world made entirely for and by clanky mechanical gizmos, is rendered with impressive skill and imagination. Otherwise, it's the usual junkyard assemblage of celebrity voices, lame pop-cultural allusions and heartwarming lessons. (Scott)    'SAHARA' (PG-13, 130 minutes). It may not be ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' but this screen adaptation of Clive Cussler's sprawling African adventure yarn is a movie that keeps half a brain in its head while adopting the amused, cocky smirk of the Indiana Jones romps. (Holden)    'SIN CITY' (R, 126 minutes). Based on the comic book series of the same name by Frank Miller, this slavishly faithful screen adaptation tracks the ups and downs of tough guys and dolls. ''Sin City'' has been made with such scrupulous care and obvious love for its genre influences that it's a shame the movie is kind of a bore. (Dargis)    * '3-IRON' (not rated, 87 minutes; in Korean). A pop fable of urban loneliness that showcases the Korean director Kim Ki-Duk's witty sense of form. It's a thoroughly modern movie with elements of silent film, a love story shot with horror-film techniques, and a charming blend of style and sentiment. (Scott)    * 'À TOUTE DE SUITE' (not rated, 96 minutes; in French). This downbeat homage to the French New Wave is a small, nearly perfect film that follows the sad chain of events when a headstrong 19-year-old art student goes on the lam with a Moroccan bank robber. (Holden)    'THE UPSIDE OF ANGER' (R, 116 minutes). The upside of this deeply flawed attempt to marry midlife romantic comedy with domestic farce is that it provides a platform for Kevin Costner and Joan Allen to do some marvelous work. (Scott)    'WALK ON WATER' (not rated, 104 minutes). The director Eytan Fox takes on the controversial subject of Israeli nationalism in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Despite an implausible climax, this movie's quiet intelligence sneaks up on you. (Dana Stevens)    'WILD SAFARI 3-D: A SOUTH AFRICAN ADVENTURE' (not rated, 45 minutes). A choppy tour of South African flora and fauna. Kids will love the romping lion cubs and elephant calves, while adults will be grateful by this travelogue's vibrancy and brevity. (Ned Martel)    'XXX: STATE OF THE UNION' (PG-13, 94 minutes). A wildly silly action flick in which all that stand between the American people and the yoke of tyranny are big guns, bigger breasts, the thud-thud-thud of commercial rap and the multiplatform artist known as Ice Cube (né O'Shea Jackson). (Dargis)    Film Series    'FIRST NATIONS/FIRST FEATURES' (Through May 23) The Museum of Modern Art's 25-film showcase of the first films of directors from indigenous cultures around the world. This weekend's offerings include ''Pathfinder'' (1987) from Norway, the story of a Sami boy who witnesses his family's murder, and two Maori features from New Zealand: ''Te Rua'' (1991) and ''Mauri'' (1988). 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)708-9400; $10, $8 for 65+, $6 for students. (Anita Gates)    'ONCE UPON A TIME: SERGIO LEONE' (Today through May 22) A cold-blooded henchman and a nameless drifter? It must be Leone (1929-89), auteur of the so-called spaghetti western. BAM Cinématek begins its 10-day Leone tribute with Henry Fonda in ''Once Upon a Time in the West'' (1968) today and tomorrow, then Clint Eastwood in ''A Fistful of Dollars'' (1964) on Sunday. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718)636-4100; $10. (Gates)    'PORGY AND BESS' (Tomorrow and Sunday) The Museum of the Moving Image is screening the only existing 35-millimeter print of Otto Preminger's 1959 musical masterpiece about life on Catfish Row. Sidney Poitier and Dorothy Dandridge play the title roles, with Sammy Davis Jr. as Sportin' Life. ''Summertime'' and ''I Got Plenty uh Nuttin' '' are just a couple of the exquisite Gershwin songs. 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718)784-0077; free with admission; museum admission: $10, $7.50 for 65+ and students, $5 for children, ages 5 to 18; free for members and children under 5. (Gates)    'MICHAEL POWELL: BEAUTY UNENDING' (Through May 31) The Film Society of Lincoln Center's major centennial tribute to this British director continues through the end of the month. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)875-5600; $10, $7 for students, $6 for members, $5 for children and 65+. (Stevens)    'WELCOME DANGER' (Through May 17) Film Forum's four-week Harold Lloyd festival winds up with his 1929 comedy about a mild-mannered botanist helping track down a Chinatown drug lord. This was a huge hit as a talkie-silent hybrid, but Lloyd kept the original silent. This is it, in a new 35-millimeter restoration of that silent, unseen for 75 years. 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212)727-8110; $10. (Gates)    Pop    Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.    TREY ANASTASIO (Tonight and Tomorrow) This leader of the now defunct jam band Phish has spent recent down time joining protégés onstage and recording a stripped-down guitar album, ditching the studio filigree of his previous solo outing. Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 6:30 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212)485-1534, $38. (Laura Sinagra)    THE BRAVERY (Monday and Tuesday) Currently braving a bit of a backlash, this muscular band was New York's Next Big Post-Strokes thing until rumored ego issues provoked skepticism among downtown fans. Monday at 8 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, (212)777-6800, $16.50. Tuesday at 9 p.m.,Warsaw, 261 Driggs Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718)387-0505, $17.50 in advance, $20 at the door. (Sinagra)    BRITISH SEA POWER, FEIST (Tomorrow and Sunday) This Brighton band puts a dreamy spin on vaguely gothic new wave with its insistent baritone vocals and bright guitar lines. Onstage it favors military garb and vertiginous hats, suggesting the ominous human forest in ''Macbeth.'' 8:30 p.m. tomorrow, 8 p.m. Sunday, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, (212)533-2111, $15 in advance, $17 at the door. (Sinagra)    BRAVE OLD WORLD: 'SONGS OF THE LODZ GHETTO' (Tonight, Tomorrow and Sunday) This accomplished klezmer group theatrically melds street and cabaret songs from the wartime Poland's Lodz ghetto within the musical frames of original Brave Old World compositions. In Yiddish, with optional projected English subtitles. Friday and Saturday at 9 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 9 p.m., Triad Theater, 158 West 72nd Street, (212)362-2590, $20. (Sinagra)    ROSANNE CASH (Tonight) The singer-songwriter Ms. Cash joins the guitarist and producer John Leventhal and the folkish band Mojo Mancini to perform songs inspired by the Himalayan art in the Rubin Museum's collection. 7 p.m., Rubin Museum of Art, 150 West 17th Street, Chelsea, (212)620-5000, $35.(Sinagra)    COLDPLAY (Tuesday) The piano-playing arena rock melodist Chris Martin brings themes of recent fatherhood to bear on his band's latest collection, which picks up the tempo a bit, but does not spawn a song to rival the band's timeless misfit cri de coeur, ''Yellow.'' Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway at 74th Street, Manhattan, (212)496-7070, tickets available through special arrangement on coldplay.com. (Sinagra)    * CRAZY TITCH, J2K, DJ CAMEO (Saturday) Another invasion from London's booming grime scene, this one led by the rowdy rhyme-spitter Crazy Titch; here's hoping the crowd is as manic as the performers. 11:30 p.m., Crash Mansion, 199 Bowery, at Spring Street, Lower East Side, (212)982-7767. $5 before 1 a.m. Sunday morning, $8 after. (Kelefa Sanneh)    THE CRYSTAL METHOD (Tomorrow) This duo specializes in loud, straightforward D.J. sets that aim to conjure up the raucous energy of hard rock. 10 p.m., Spirit, 530 W. 27th Street, near 10th Avenue, Chelsea, (212)268-9477, $25 in advance, $30 at the door. (Sanneh)    LILY CUSHMAN CULHANE (Sunday) This singer-songwriter's tracks recall the trip-pop favored by wistful optimists like Dido and Jem. Her honeyed jazzy vocal technique sets her apart. 9:30 p.m., Pianos, 158 Ludlow Street, near Stanton Street, (212)420-1466, $7. (Sinagra)    DONNA THE BUFFALO AND HACKENSAW BOYS (Tonight) Donna the Buffalo's good-natured rock leans toward the Appalachian side of country, also dipping into reggae and Cajun music, with songs that ponder love and humanity's place in the universe. 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111, $18. (Jon Pareles)    DOVES, MERCURY REV (Wednesday and Thursday) The Doves bring a rough ''Madchester'' dance pedigree to their sweeping guitar pop, making the trio's music slightly edgier than other big- room British acts like Coldplay. Enduring space-rockers Mercury Rev open. 7 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212)353-1600, $30.(Sinagra)    DR JOHN: 'ALL BY HISSELF' (Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and May 20-21 and May 25-29) Dr. John is steeped in New Orleans barrelhouse piano, swampy bayou funk and the gris-gris mysticism that surrounds it. He has applied his cagey growl of a voice and florid piano playing to jazz standards and songs with a conscience. 8 p.m., except May 20-21 and May 27-29 when shows are at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m. Au Bar, 41 East 58th Street, Manhattan, (212)308-9455, $50. (Pareles)    DOC WATSON (Wednesday) Doc Watson is the embodiment of a mountain-music heritage. He's an understated master of a rural repertory that spans blues, bluegrass, country and ragtime, and he's a flatpicking guitar whiz whose leads rush by like a pine-scented breeze. 7 p.m., B.B. King's Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, (212)997-4144, $30 in advance, $35 at the door. (Pareles)    EL VEZ (Tomorrow) Most Elvis imitators are corny; El Vez is conceptual, merging Presleyana, Mexican-American in-jokes and bad puns to simultaneously honor and twist the Presley legacy. 10:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212)260-4700, $15. (Pareles)    GANG OF FOUR (Tuesday and Wednesday) In a season of reunions, the legendary British post-punk sloganeers Gang of Four bring their angular dance-rock back onto a circuit rife with young imitators. 9 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, (212)777-6800, $25. (Sinagra)    * THE GOOD LIFE (Tonight) This band is the quieter project from singer-songwriter Tim Kasher (who also leads the knotty emo act Cursive); expect to hear hushed, densely written songs from the strong recent Good Life CD, ''Album of the Year'' (Saddle Creek), on which the pairings are even sadder than the splittings. 9 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3006, $14.(Sanneh)    PAUL GREEN SCHOOL OF ROCK PRESENTS 'THE WALL' (Tonight and Tomorrow) Philadelphia's Paul Green and his real-life ''School of Rock'' are featured in the recent documentary ''Rock School'' (NewMarket). There the little shredders play Frank Zappa. Here they assay Pink Floyd's opus. 7 p.m., TriBeCa Rock Club, 16 Warren Street, (212)766-1070, $10. (Sinagra)    DAVID GRISMAN (Wednesday) Before phrases like ''new acoustic music'' or ''bluegrass revival'' were being bandied around, David Grisman was picking his mandolin in what he named ''dawg music,'' a perfectly noncommital moniker for string-band music that cheerfully picked its way through country, bluegrass, jazz, klezmer, Brazilian choros and whatever else Mr. Grisman finds engaging. 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, (212)840-2824, $30 to $50. (Pareles)    GYPSY MUSIC OF ROMANIA: TARAF DE HAIDOUKS (Tomorrow) Hailing from the village of Clejani, Romania, this Roma music outfit showcases deft fiddle, accordion and cimbalom arrangements of whirlwind dance music and traditional ballads. 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212)840-2824, $25 to $40, college students with ID, $15.(Sinagra)    * NEIL HAMBURGER (Tonight) This meta-comedian, who bills himself as ''America's funnyman,'' excels when the audience hates him (or pretends to); tonight, he may well find himself face to face with a roomful of fans, armed only with repulsive punchlines, awkward silences, and an ill-fitting suit. Expect a magical night. 8 p.m., Pianos, 158 Ludlow Street, near Stanton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 505-3733, $8. (Sanneh)    HEARTLESS BASTARDS (Wednesday) The southern Ohio singer and guitarist Erika Wennerstrom's primal yowl gets her compared to Robert Plant and Polly Harvey. Her power trio's hungry stomp is heavy enough for classic rockers and post-ironic enough for hipsters looking for bar band sincerity. 9:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212)260-4700, $10.(Sinagra)    THE HOLD STEADY (Thursday) With smart swagger, the Hold Steady savant Craig Finn spews an almost unseemly amount of pop culture references in a voice that recalls Bruce Springsteen. 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111. $13 in advance $15 at the door. (Sinagra)    KASABIAN (Monday and Tuesday) Don't let their namesake, Charles Manson's getaway driver, fool you. The band's mix of classic rock and electronic music is perfectly harmless. 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111, $16 in advance, $18 at the door. (Sinagra)    PETER MURPHY (Monday) This goth rock heartthrob and leader of 80's dark side pioneers Bauhaus has a cult audience that of late has followed him on forays into Middle Eastern sonics. His most recent record is a poppier bid. 11:30 p.m., B.B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, (212)997-4144, $35. (Sinagra)    THE PHARCYDE (Tonight) With the departure of the memorable potheads Slimkid and Fatlip, these California backpack rappers' goofy mid-90's charm waned well before the turn of the century. But the two founders, Imani and Bootie Brown, still release albums and will perfrom with a band late and off the beaten track. 11 p.m., the Hook, 18 Commerce Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (718)797-3007, $14. (Sinagra)    WILLY PORTER (Monday) An impressive purveyor of rapid-fingered acoustic guitar technique, Mr. Porter has developed a gentle vocal style that smartly softens what might otherwise seem overly crafty. 7 p.m., Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212)239-6200, $20. (Sinagra).    PURPLE CITY AND FRIENDS, THEODORE UNIT (Tomorrow) An offshoot of Cam'ron's Harlem's hip-op crew the Diplomats', Purple City performs material from its new record, along with the Ghostface Killah side project Theodore Unit and the Bed Stuy story-rapper Spec Booge. D.J. sets by the mix tape mavens DJ Mighty Mi and DJ Catchdubs. 11 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3006, $12, $14 at the door. (Sinagra)    JOEY RAMONE BIRTHDAY BASH (Thursday) This annual event turns lingering grief over the 2001 death of the Ramones frontman into a kinetic celebration of the band's legacy. Guests include the younger punks like the Bouncing Souls as well as veterans like the Dictators' Andy Shernoff and Lunachick Theo. 8 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, 212-777-6800, $25, sold out. (Sinagra)    SAMITE (Tomorrow) This Ugandan singer and storyteller surrounds his gentle voice with the twinkling intricacies of his kalimba (thumb piano), marimba or lintungu (lyre). 8 p.m. Satalla, 37 West 26th, (212)576-1155, Chelsea, $18 in advance, $20 at the door. (Pareles)    BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN (Thursday) The Boss made ''The Rising'' after the towers fell, beating the novelist Jonathan Safran Foer to the notion of reverse-collapse by four years. Mr. Springsteen's spare ''Devils and Dust'' (Sony) charts the way back down, meditating with other soul-searchers at the crossroads of humanism and religion. 7:30 p.m., Continental Airlines Arena, the Meadowlands, Route 120, East Rutherford, N.J., (201)935-3900, $75 and $85, sold out. (Sinagra)    STING (Tonight) This adult-contemporary pop superstar's most recent material continues to explore aging, romance and rich-guy guilt over lush world-music-inflected instrumentation. Joss Stone, the young English blues belter and current star of a summer Gap ad, opens. 8 p.m., Tommy Hilfiger at Jones Beach Theater, 1000 Ocean Parkway, Wantagh, N.Y., (516)221-1000, $33 to $86. (Sinagra)    SUPAGROUP (Wednesday) Known for their raucous stage show, this AC/DC-loving Louisiana four-piece tears through its countrified punk and riff-raff metal repertory with the kind of abandon that more manicured garage bands lack. 10 p.m., Snitch, 59 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212)727-7775, free. (Sinagra)    U2 (Tuesday and Wednesday) After 2000's thrilling ''All that You Can't Leave Behind'' (Interscope), ''How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb'' (Interscope) and the ''Vertigo'' tour itself focus on what humans can live without: namely ICBM's and, evidently, some of U2's more shopworn live staples. Hence the vivid resurrection of decades-old rarities like ''Electric Co.'' 7:30 p.m., Continental Airlines Arena, the Meadowlands, Route 120, East Rutherford, N.J., (201)935-3900, $51.50 to $167, sold out. (Sinagra)    VELVET REVOLVER (Tomorrow) Comparing the druggy baritone of the former Stone Temple Pilots frontman Scott Weilland to the feral howl of vintage Axl Rose is unfair. But even without Axl, the former Guns n' Roses guitarist Slash and crew are still aces at groovy, scruffy metal. 8 p.m., Jones Beach Theater, 1000 Ocean Pkwy., Wantagh, N.Y., (516)221-1000, $20 to $65. (Sinagra)    YO LA TENGO: THE SOUNDS OF SCIENCE (Wednesday) The Hoboken indie-rock icons known for rendering both the quiet spaces and explosive pathos of committed love perform an original score to the short films of the oceanographer Jean Painlevés. 8 p.m., Rose Theater at Lincoln Center, Broadway at 60th Street, (212)258-9800, $40. (Sinagra)    Cabaret    Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music.    * KAREN AKERS (Tuesdays through Saturdays) Classic romantic ballads gracefully rendered by a statue come to life. Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212)419-9331, through May 28. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 9 and 11:30 p.m. Cover is $50; a $50 prixe fixe dinner is required Thursdays through Saturdays at 9; otherwise, a $20 minimum. (Stephen Holden)    BARBARA CARROLL (Sundays at 2 and 8 p.m.) Even when swinging out, this Lady of a Thousand Songs remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Oak Room (see above). Cover: $55 at 2, including brunch at noon; $42 at 8, plus a $15 minimum; an $80 dinner-and-show package is available. (Holden)    * BARBARA COOK (Tuesdays through Saturdays) Now 77, the great lyric soprano pays tribute to her longtime musical director Wally Harper who died last October, and other friends who are gone. Ms. Cook's performances are master classes in life as well as in singing. Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212)744-1600, through May 27. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8:45 p.m.; Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m. Cover is $75 Tuesdays through Thursdays, $90 on Fridays and Saturdays. (Holden)    * 'SINGING ASTAIRE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) With Eric Comstock, Hilary Kole and Christopher Gines. The vocal trio that created the smart revue ''Our Sinatra'' has outdone itself with this lightly swinging 70-minute compendium of songs and lore associated with Fred Astaire. Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212)581-3080. 5:30 p.m. Cover: $30, with a $10 minimum at a table. (Holden)    Jazz    Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.    JOHN ABERCROMBIE GROUP (Through tomorrow) With the lineup that accompanies him this week -- Mark Feldman on violin, Joey Baron on drums, Marc Johnson on bass -- Mr. Abercrombie, a guitarist, has made the recent albums, ''Cat 'n' Mouse'' and ''Class Trip,'' two of his best. 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, (212)581-3080, cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Ben Ratliff)    * JD ALLEN TRIO (Wednesday) A tenor saxophonist with an enigmatic, elegant and hard-driving style, putting an original spin on a Wayne Shorterish idiom. 10 p.m., Zebulon, 258 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718)218-6934, no cover. (Ratliff)    PATRICIA BARBER (Through Sunday) A dry, smart, passionate and original singer-songwriter-pianist. Tonight and Sunday at 8 p.m., tomorrow at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Le Jazz Au Bar, 41 East 58th Street, Manhattan, (212)308-9455, cover, $50 tonight and tomorrow, $35 Sunday, and a two-drink minimum all nights. (Ratliff)    * ANDY BISKIN'S GOLDBERG VARIATIONS (Through Sunday) That's Goldberg as in Rube Goldberg. Andy Biskin, a jazz clarinetist with a low-key sense of humor, composed a series of pieces around Goldberg's elaborately wacky inventions, and also animated the original drawings. So what you get is a dozen jazz tone poems scored for sextet, with film accompaniment, about how to grow hair on balding men or how to light a cigar in a speeding car. It's an all-ages piece of work, and kids are especially welcome at the matinee performances. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., and tomorrow and Sunday at noon, Bowery Poetry Club, 308 Bowery at Bleecker, East Village, (212)614-0505, $15, $10 for children under 12. (Ratliff)    * PETER BRÖTZMANN CHICAGO TENTET (Wednesday) In the last decade, Peter Brötzmann, the German saxophonist, has become a father figure for American free-jazz musicians. His Tentet has a revolving cast but usually includes some of the cream of the Chicago scene (like the saxophonist Ken Vandermark); this week it also has musicians from Germany, Norway and Sweden. Its music is far from completely free, making shrewd use of conducting and arrangements -- a good thing for Mr. Brötzmann, whose bellowing tone could rip a hole in the wall. 8 and 10 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212)358-7501, $15. (Ratliff)    GERALD CLAYTON GROUP (Tomorrow) A young pianist, the son of the bassist John Clayton, here leads a band including some excellent musicians -- the vibraphonist Stefon Harris, the saxophonist Tim Warfield and the drummer Obed Calvaire. 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212)242-1063, $15. (Ratliff)    JACK DEJOHNETTE WITH FODAY MUSA SUSO AND JEROME HARRIS (Tonight) Mr. DeJohnette, one of the great jazz drummers to come along since the 1960's, collaborates with the Gambian kora player Foday Musa Suso; they'll play music from a new album, ''Music From the Hearts of the Masters,'' released on Mr. DeJohnette's own label, Golden Beams. 7 and 9:30, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212)539-8770, cover, $25. (Ratliff)    * MARTY EHRLICH'S DARK WOODS FIVE (Wednesday) One of the saxophonist/clarinetist Mr. Ehrlich's best-sounding groups, comprised of all-wood instruments: Mark Feldman on violin, Erik Friedlander on cello, Alan Jaffe on guitar and Mark Helias on bass. 8 and 10 p.m., Barbes, 376 9th Street at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718)965-9177, $8. (Ratliff)    * 'ESSENTIALLY ELLINGTON' CONCERT (Sunday) By the time you get to Avery Fisher Hall, 15 high school jazz bands have been through semifinals, playing Ellington before eminent judges to earn a spot among the top three that you'll hear in concert. The ''Essentially Ellington'' international high school jazz-band contest, produced and organized by Jazz at Lincoln Center -- this is the 10th annual -- is designed to be fun to watch, and it's also a reliable indicator of just how good the next crop of professional jazz musicians will be. 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, 65th Street and Broadway, Manhattan, (212)721-6500, $20. (Ratliff)    CURTIS FULLER QUINTET (Through tomorrow) The trombonist formerly from Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers still soulfully showing how it's done. 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue at 38th Street, Manhattan, (212) 885-7000 , cover, $20. (Ratliff)    BENNY GOLSON QUARTET (Through tomorrow) The tenor saxophonist Mr. Golson, in his mid-70's, is an unlikely jazz hero: upbeat, fascinated with technique, a nonpurist who has spent equal time among the different aesthetic dispositions of East and West Coast jazz. 9, 11 and 12:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway at 106th Street, Manhattan, (212)864-6662, cover, $25. (Ratliff)    ANDREW HILL 'RETRO' QUARTET (Wednesday and Thursday) The pianist Andrew Hill is one of the most mysterious composers of modern jazz, not just for his fraught harmonies and layered rhythms but for his periodic disappearances from the scene. But he's come back over the last decade, leading a number of bands; this is a quartet with the saxophonist Greg Tardy, the bassist John Hebert and the drummer Leroi Jones. 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, (212)581-3080, cover, $30. (Ratliff)    BOBBY HUTCHERSON QUARTET (Tuesday through Thursday) Mr. Hutcherson is one of the great individual voices and better composers in jazz, and he's a vibraphonist, making him triply rare. After 40 years, he still sounds current. The band includes pianist Mike LeDonne, the bassist Dwayne Burno and the drummer Billy Drummond. 9 and 11 p.m. Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212)255-4037, cover, $30. (Ratliff)    JUILLIARD JAZZ ORCHESTRA: 'CELEBRATING ELLINGTON' (Through Sunday) A band featuring students in Juilliard's Institute for Jazz Studies, conducted by Victor Goines and featuring the singer Vanessa Rubin and the saxophonist Frank Wess. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 5th Floor, 60th Street and Broadway, (212)258-9800, cover, $30. (Ratliff)    BIRELI LAGRENE'S MUSIC OF DJANGO REINHARDT (Through Sunday) Mr. Lagrene, a Sinti Gypsy like Django Reinhardt and one of the most talented guitarists to have adopted his style, is a more sensitive, temperate musician than many of his fellow Djangophiles; this is his sextet. Tonight and tomorrow nights at 8, 10 and 11:30; Sunday at 8 and 10. Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, (212)582-2121, cover, $32.50, today and Sunday, $35 tomorrow, with a $10 minimum. (Ratliff)    * LINCOLN CENTER ORCHESTRA PLAYS THAD JONES (Thursday) The trumpeter and composer Thad Jones, who died in 1986, always deserves a second look. A member of Count Basie's orchestra during the 1950's and early 60's, he decamped to form his own big band which played weekly shows at the Village Vanguard, starting a new large-ensemble jazz tradition. Jazz at Lincoln Center's gleaming band takes on his music, with the saxophonists Jerry Dodgion and Billy Harper and the bass trombonist Douglas Purviance, as guests; Vincent Gardner, one of Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra's trombonists, presents new arrangements of the old tunes. 8 p.m., Rose Theater, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, (212)721-6500. $30 to $150. (Ratliff)    JOE LOVANO WITH MULGREW MILER, GEORGE MRAZ, PAUL MOTIAN: MUSIC OF THAD JONES (Tuesday through Thursday) It's the fascinating band from Mr. Lovano's last two albums, with the pianist Mulgrew Miller subbing for Hank Jones. They're playing Thad Jones pieces all week (there are some on Mr. Lovano's new album ''Joyous Encounter''), stylistically rolling the last 50 years of jazz history around. 7:30 and 9:30, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, (212)258-9800, cover, $30. (Ratliff)    BILL McHENRY TRIO (Tuesday) Like players decades ago, the tenor saxophonist Mr. McHenry puts his big, round sound before anything else; he likes playing slowly and choosing his moves, guided compositionally by Ornette Coleman and emotionally by Don Byas. 9:30 p.m., Nublu, 62 Avenue C, between Fourth and Fifth Streets, East Village, www.nublu.net, cover, $5. (Ratliff)    MISHA MENGELBERG (Through Sunday) The legendary Dutch jazz pianist, a practitioner of wise mischief, in a series of collaborations. Tonight with Frances-Marie Uitti and Ikue Mori; tomorrow with Mark Feldman; Sunday with John Zorn. 8 and 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C at 2nd Street, East Village, www.thestonenyc.com, $15. (Ratliff)    * BEN MONDER QUARTET (Tuesday and Wednesday) Ben Monder has played nearly unsurpassable modern jazz guitar with any number of actual jazz groups. But what he plays in his own group comes from another planet: it is exploratory, meditative, and a little eerie, with Theo Bleckman often singing wordlessly on top of the music. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, (212)576-2232, cover, $20. (Ratliff)    ROY NATHANSON QUARTET (Sunday) The saxophonist Mr. Nathanson was always the principal composer of the long-running band the Jazz Passengers, and his pieces often included bits of jokes and stories; here, with a band including the violinist Sam Bardfeld, the bassist Tim Kaya and the drummer Gerald Cleaver, he's focusing on new pieces that more deeply combine spoken narratives with music. 7 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718)965-9177, $8. (Ratliff)    STEVE NELSON QUARTET (Through tomorrow) One of New York's best jazz musicians for a long time now, and one of the best parts of Dave Holland's quintet, Mr. Nelson brings his own band to the stage, with the pianist Mulgrew Miller, the bassist Robert Hurst and the drummer Lewis Nash. 8, 10 and midnight, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212)255-3626, cover, $20. (Ratliff)    OREGON (Wednesday and Thursday) Celtic music, jazz, swing and classical guitar get all mixed up in the music of Oregon, a band that's been around since 1970. The band rarely comes around anymore, and the lineup is as it has been, more or less, for ages: Ralph Towner on guitar, Paul McCandless on oboe, Glen Moore on bass, Mark Walker on drums. 8 and 10 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, Midtown, (212)582-2121, cover, $27.50. (Ratliff)    GRETCHEN PARLATO (Monday) The jazz singer Ms. Parlato is a newcomer of great promise: in standards, bossa novas and originals, through long tones and subtle inflections of rhythm, she deeply enters the musical field of her band. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212)576-2232, cover, $15. (Ratliff)    BOBBY PREVITE/DAVE BINNEY GROUP (Wednesday) The drummer and saxophonist both write music bubbling with diverse influences and busy grooves; they lead this quartet, which includes the guitarist Adam Rogers and the bassist Eivind Opsvik. 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212)929-9883, cover, $10. (Ratliff)    TIM RIES'S THE STONES PROJECT (Through Sunday) Having toured twice as tenor saxophonist with the Rolling Stones, Mr. Ries has put together an album, ''The Stones Project,'' with a revolving crew of musicians including Charlie Watts, Keith Richards and Ron Wood. This week it's the jazz-playing core of the project, though: the guitarist Ben Monder, the organist Larry Goldings, the drummer Greg Hutchinson. 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212)576-2232, cover, $25 and $20 on Sunday. (Ratliff)    JENNY SCHEINMAN (Tuesday) The violinist Ms. Scheinman has made some eclectic and carefully composed records. But as these more low-key weekly gigs prove, at bottom she's a killer player, with the street musician's trick of getting attention by the power of the single, perfect note. Next week she appears with the guitarist Adam Levy. 7 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718)965-9177 , $8. (Ratliff)    JEREMY STEIG QUARTET (Tonight) A flutist who has been playing in New York jazz and rock circles since the early 1960's. 9 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212)989-9319, cover, $12. (Ratliff)    E.J. STRICKLAND PROJECT (Tonight) With John Ellis, Myron Walden, Mike Moreno, Boris Kozlov, Gretchen Parlato, Charenee Wade. 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212)242-1063, $15. (Ratliff)    * McCOY TYNER TRIO WITH GARY BARTZ, RAVI COLTRANE, AND TERRELL STAFFORD (Through Sunday) The pianist from John Coltrane's classic quartet brings his current trio with some horn-playing guests. 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212)475-8592, cover, $40. (Ratliff)    VISION CLUB: CHARLES WATERS' GOLD SPARKLE TRIO/MARTY EHRLICH (Tomorrow) The Gold Sparkle Band has been in New York since the late 80's; it channels the East Coast jazz avant-garde of the mid-1960's. Mr. Ehrlich, one of the musicians who bridged the avant-garde with the jazz tradition in the 70's and 80's, is always exploring a worthwhile avenue with a different band. This one features the saxophonist Michael Attias, the pianist Craig Taborn and the drummer Pheeroan AkLaff. Gold Sparkle at 9:30 p.m., Mr. Ehrlich at 11 p.m. Clemente Soto Velez Gallery, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side, (212)696-6681 or www.visionfestival.org, $15. (Ratliff)    Classical    Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.    Opera    'LA BOHÈME' (Tonight and Tomorrow) Impressive endurance, at the very least, is a hallmark of the Bronx Opera, which for 36 seasons has been offering young professionals in fully staged opera productions, on a minimal budget, with occasionally pleasing results. 8 p.m., Lovinger Theater, Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, in the Bronx, (718)960-8833, $15 to $30. (Anne Midgette)    'LA CLEMENZA DI TITO' (Tomorrow) Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production of Mozart's great venture into opera seria gets star treatment from James Levine, Heidi Grant Murphy and Anne Sofie von Otter. 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000, $145 to $215 remaining. (Bernard Holland)    'L'ELISIR D'AMORE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Run on enthusiasm and a shoestring, the tiny Amato Opera company mounts a modest production of the Donizetti classic. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2:30, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212)228-8200, $30, $25 for students and 65+. (Jeremy Eichler)    'FAUST' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) In a revelatory performance, James Levine cuts through the hokum of Gounod's ''Faust'' and captures the music's dignity and elegance. And the Met has assembled a top-rank cast, especially René Pape as Mephistopheles. Alas, the Met's new production by Andrei Serban is a jumble. Though the conductor Steven Crawford takes over for tomorrow evening's performance, Mr. Levine returns on Wednesday. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000, $145 and $215 remaining tomorrow, sold out on Wednesday but returns may be available. (Anthony Tommasini)    'LOST CHILDHOOD' (Wednesday) Yehuda Nir's harrowing Holocaust memoir makes a strange choice for an opera, but Janice Hamer, a composer, and Mary Azrael, a librettist, have made it into one, and the results may be powerful. 7:30 p.m., Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, (646)505-4445, $20. (Allan Kozinn)    'TOSCA' (Monday and Thursday) For some, the draw is Franco Zeffirelli's lavish and historically authentic production. For others, the main attraction comes on Thursday, when the soprano Aprile Millo makes one of her now-rare Metropolitan Opera appearances in the title role. 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House (see above), $26 to $170. (Midgette)    Classical Music    'THE ANDSNES PROJECT' (Tonight) The remarkable Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes concludes his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall this season with a bracing chamber music program of works by Kurtag and Schumann. Joining him are some adventurous young musicians, including several fellow Scandinavians. 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212)247-7800, $32 to $45. (Tommasini)    BARGEMUSIC (Tonight, tomorrow, Sunday and Thursday) Great views and typically fresh performances help make this floating concert hall one of the best for chamber music. This weekend, the young pianist Helen Huang performs a solo recital and in a program of small ensemble works. Thursday, it's Olga Vinokur playing Russian piano music. Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday at 7:30; Sunday at 4 p.m. Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718)624-2083, $35, $25 for students; $30 for 65+ on Thursdays. (Eichler)    BROOKLYN CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY (Tonight) Some top-tier artists are associated with the Brooklyn Chamber Music Society, including the violinist Carmit Zori, the cellist Timothy Eddy and the pianist Gilbert Kalish. A program tonight offers works by Haydn, Chausson, Beethoven and George Crumb. 8, First Unitarian Church, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights, (718)858-0718, $30. (Tommasini)    CANTERBURY CHORAL SOCIETY (Sunday) Handel's ''Esther'' expands a bit on the Biblical story, but it has some great choral writing, not to mention a important place in the composer's history: his first oratorio. 4 p.m., Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, (212)222-9458, $20, $10 for students and 65+, free for children 12. (Kozinn)    CANTICUM NOVUM SINGERS (Tomorrow and Sunday) Harold Rosenbaum leads the self-described ''elite amateur'' chorus in a program that concludes its 32nd season with works by Britten, Vaughan Williams, John Harbison and others. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., St. Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th Street, Manhattan, (212)279-4200, $20. (Eichler)    CERDDORION (Sunday) The vocal ensemble celebrates its 10th anniversary with a program of the very early (Josquin, Monteverdi) and the very new, including works it commissioned in the past year and a new piece by David Lang. 7:30 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212)501-3330, $25, $50 for a VIP ticket including a post-concert reception. (Midgette)    CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday) A mighty instrument serves two masters, Pierre Boulez and Daniel Barenboim, in landmark works of Bach, Beethoven, Bartok, Mahler and others. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800, $29 to $120. (James R. Oestreich)    SARAH CONNOLLY (Monday) If this recital is anything like as good as her New York recital debut three years ago, one should run, not walk, to hear this fine British mezzo present a program that ranges from Haydn, Brahms and Reynaldo Hahn to Korngold and Kurt Weill. 7:30, Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800, $32. (Midgette)    DA CAPO CHAMBER PLAYERS (Sunday) These reliable musicians perform an electronica program of classic and contemporary works for instruments and tape. The bill includes Steve Reich's ''New York Counterpoint,'' Arthur Kreiger's ''Meeting Places'' and Mario Davidovsky's ''Synchronisms No. 6.'' 7:30 p.m., the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3006, $15, $10 for students and 65+. A panel discussion on technology and art takes place at 6:30 p.m. (Eichler)    EARLY MUSIC NEW YORK (Tomorrow) Maybe period instrument groups have been devoting too much thought to timbre and too little to sex: in the quest for greater authenticity, Frederick Renz has assembled an all-woman orchestra to play works Vivaldi wrote for the young ladies in his charge at Ospedale della Pietà, in Venice. 8 p.m., St. James Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, (212)280-0330, $35. (Kozinn)    JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA (Thursday) It's out with old, in the Juilliard School's annual commencement concert, conducted by Raymond Leppard. The new comes with the actual commencement the next morning, ushering in celebrations of the school's centenary. 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)769-7406, free but tickets are required. (Oestreich)    MADAME VERA GALUPE-BORSZKH (Tonight and Tomorrow) You don't have to love opera to roar with laughter at Madame Vera, although the diva (by day, the director and voice coach Ira Siff) would frown at a term as crass as ''spoof'' for her brilliant send-ups of the singer's art. 8 p.m., Thalia at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, (212)864-5400, $30, $25 for students and 65+. (Midgette)    ANTON NEL (Wednesday) At his recital debut, in the late 1980's, this pianist was polished if interpretively predictable, but encounters since then suggest that he has grown considerably. Here he tackles a hefty program that runs from Mozart to John Corigliano. 8 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800, $15. (Kozinn)    NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Thursday) Neeme Jarvi, who takes over as music director next season, ends this one with a program of Beethoven's Triple Concerto (with the Eroica Trio) and Mahler's Fourth Symphony. 8 p.m., State Theater, New Brunswick, N.J., (800)255-3476, $24 to $82. (Oestreich)    PRISM CONCERTS (Sunday) The Central Synagogue, with its big new organ installed, inaugurates a series with ''A Sacred Bond,'' a program commemorating the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II. Judith Clurman is the artistic director. 7:30 p.m., Lexington Avenue at 55th Street, (212)868-4444, $20 and $30. (Oestreich)    QUEEN'S CHAMBER BAND (Tuesday) An early-music group goes mostly modern, with premieres by José Bernardo, Robert Baska, Marshall Coid, Ray Bono and Joseph Fennimore. And oh, yes, there's Bach, from ''The Art of Fugue.'' 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212)501-3330, $25, with half price for students and 65+. (Oestreich)    'SOUND PROJECTIONS' (Wednesday) Silent films and live music are the focus of this mini-festival. This week's installment brings the veteran indie band Yo La Tengo to accompany eight short films, including ''The Love Life of the Octopus,'' by the oceanographer and avant-garde filmmaker Jean Painlevé (1902-89). 8 p.m., Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212)721-6500, $40. (Midgette)    ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE (Sunday and Monday) The core players of the Orchestra of St. Luke's turn their attention to Baroque works, including Handel's lively ''Water Music.'' Sunday at 2 p.m., the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, (212)594-6100, $25. The concert is repeated Monday at 6:30 p.m., Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, free. (Kozinn)    VOICES OF ASCENSION (Tuesday) You can never have too much Bach, and this wonderful choir (with orchestral support) is offering plenty, with the Magnificat in D as the centerpiece of an all-Bach program. 8 p.m., the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, Greenwich Village, (212)358-1469, $10 to $45; half price for students. (Kozinn)    WESTERN WIND (Tonight) This fine, flexible vocal sextet offers a historical tour of love songs, from the great Renaissance and early Baroque composers (Dowland, Monteverdi, Tomkins) through classic jazz and pop (Ellington and Lennon-McCartney). 8 p.m., Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street, West Village, (212)873-2848, $15 to $100. (Kozinn)    Dance    Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.    * 'AILEY II AT THE APOLLO' (Tonight and tomorrow) The Ailey junior troupe celebrates its 30th birthday at another resonant city institution. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212)307-7171, $20 to $40; $12 student tickets available in person, cash only, noon to 6 p.m. day of performance. (Jennifer Dunning)    LORI BELILOVE & COMPANY (Tomorrow) Dances by Isadora Duncan, in a free performance by a company that includes the ''Belilovable'' child dancers. 2:30 p.m., Donnell Library Center Auditorium, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)621-0619. (Dunning)    H.T. CHEN AND DANCERS (Opens Thursday) In ''Heart of Grace,'' a Shanghai-born choreographer frees a human being caged inside a mythological lion. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)924-0077 or www.dtw.org, $25, $15 for students and seniors, through May 22. (Jack Anderson)    'DANCE AND POLITICS: DOES IT MATTER?' (Tomorrow) We hope so. 2 to 6 p.m. Laban/Bartenieff Institute of Movement Studies, 520 Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, (212)643-8888, free but donations are requested. (Dunning)    * DANCE AT CONSTRUCTION COMPANY (Sunday and Monday) The thought-provoking pleasures of a salon, with dances this time by Sally Bowden, Scott Caywood, Beth Leonard, Elaine Shipman and Linda Seifert. 8 p.m., Construction Company, 10 East 18th Street, Manhattan, (212)924-7882, $15, $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning)    * DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM OPEN HOUSE (Sunday) A down-home afternoon with company members and guests who include the musicians Andy Bey, Alfredo Valdes Jr. and Thomas Buckner as well as members of the Federation of Black Cowboys. 3:30 p.m. Everett Center for the Performing Arts, 466 West 152nd Street, Harlem, (212)690-2800, $18, $14 for children 12 and under. (Dunning)    DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP 2005 GALA CELEBRATION (Monday) Big Dance Theater, the Bebe Miller Company, David Neumann, Paradigm and the Stephen Petronio Company help honor the achievements of the dance photographer Lois Greenfield. 7 p.m.; dinner reception follows, New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Theater District, (212)691-6500, ext. 377, $300 to $1,000 for performance and reception, $75 performance only. (Anderson)    * HILARY EASTON (Opening Thursday) A humanist with a mind and muscles, Ms. Easton presents her new ''Short-Cut,'' inspired by the work of the efficiency expert Frederick Winslow Taylor. Thursday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212)674-8194, $15 or TDF voucher, through May 22. (Dunning)    ESSE AFICIONADO (Tonight through Sunday) The modern-dance company with the strange name, in Judson Dance Theater-inspired work by the founding member Gina Graham. 8 p.m., Joan Weill Center for Dance, 405 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212)560-4825, $15, $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning)    EXTENDED DANCE THEATER (Tonight through Sunday) Choreography by company director Val Suarez, inspired in part by the writing of William Butler Yeats. Tonight at 9, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Steps Studio Theater, 2121 Broadway, Manhattan, edtnyc@hotmail.com, $15, $10 for students. (Dunning)    * LAWRENCE GOLDHUBER/BIGMANARTS (Tonight through Sunday) Mr. Goldhuber's new ''Julius Caesar Superstar'' sounds like a frolic, featuring as it does ballet's Robert La Fosse and such diverse denizens of downtown dance as Arthur Aviles, Thom Fogarty, Keely Garfield and Micki Wesson. Tonight through Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212)674-8194, $15 or TDF voucher. (Dunning)    ''JOYCE SOHO PRESENTS'' (Tonight and tomorrow) Eight young 'uns show their stuff in programs Thursdays through Saturdays through May 21. All performances at 8 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212)334-7479, $15, $12 for students and 65+. (Dunning)    FIONA MARCOTTY-DOLENGA AND COMPANY (Tonight through Sunday) Their new ''Paradise Strategies'' is a dance about trying to get to heaven, and the winner of the week's award for best title. Tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 p.m.; Sunday at 5 p.m., West End Theater, 263 West 86th Street, Manhattan, (212)337-9565, $15, $12 for artists. (Dunning)    * NETA DANCE COMPANY (Tonight through next Sunday) Two different programs of dances by Neta Pulvermacher that draw on everything from childhood memories of a kibbutz to orchids. Tonight and tomorrow (and Wednesday and Thursday) at 7 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m, Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212)352-3101 or www.netacompany.org, $20, through May 22. (Dunning)    'THE NEW, NEW STUFF SERIES' (Tonight through Sunday) Christopher Williams' new ''Ursula and the 11,000 Virgins'' will be performed by a cast that includes Vicky Shick, Wendy Perron and Elizabeth Zimmer. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., Sunday at 5 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212)477-5288, $15, $12 for students. (Dunning)    * NOCHE FLAMENCA (Through June 6) Flamenco dance and music, understated, intimate and beautifully staged. Wednesdays and Thursdays at 7:30 p.m., Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 and 10 p.m., Sundays at 5 p.m., Theater 80, 80 St. Mark's Place, East Village, (212)352-3101, $40 (Wednesdays and Thursdays); $45 (Fridays through Sundays). (Dunning)    SABA DANCE THEATER (Opens tonight) ''Three'' sets the blue, white and red of the French flag choreographically waving. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212)307-4100 or www.ticketmaster.com, $30, $25 for students. (Anderson)    LIZ SARGENT (Tonight through May 21) An attraction in the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council's SiteLines series, ''Returning,'' permits audiences to travel through a glass space and behold images of constantly revolving dancers. Tonight at 5:30 and 7:30, tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., 15 Nassau Street, Lower Manhattan, (212)219-9401, free. (Anderson)    SILVER-BROWN DANCE COMPANY (Opens tonight) Eva Silverstein has based ''Raise High'' on a J.D. Salinger story and her dance bounds from jitterbugging to hip-hop. Tonight (a gala) and tomorrow at 7:30, Ailey Studios, Joan Weill Center for Dance, 405 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (917)482-8404 or silverbrowndance@aol.com, $50 tonight, $20 tomorrow. (Anderson)    'WAXWORKS RETURNS!' (Sunday) A monthly Sunday showcase for dance, and other lesser forms of theater, by new and seasoned performing artists. Sunday at 7 p.m., University Settlement House, 184 Eldridge Street, Lower East Side, (718)599-7997 or www.wax205.com, $10. (Dunning)    'WHEN PATHS COLLIDE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) A three-troupe program, by Alison Seidenstricker's ASEID Contemporary Dance Company, Heather Granger's Mad Cap Dance and the Allison Vinal-Kelly Collins Dualdance. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3:30 and 7:30 pm., Clark Studio Theater, Rose Building, Lincoln Center, (212)501-2456, $25, $15 for students and 65+. (Dunning)    Art    Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.    Museums    * AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM: 'ANCESTRY AND INNOVATION: AFRICAN AMERICAN ART FROM THE COLLECTION,' through Sept. 4. This selection of quilts, paintings, sculptures and drawings by several generations of self-taught artists jumps with color and talent and reflects a sharp curatorial eye. 45 West 53rd Street (212)265-1040. (Roberta Smith)    AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM: 'SELF AND SUBJECT,' through Sept. 11. From Grandma Moses's view of herself beguiled by infant descendants to A.G. Rizzoli's rendition of his mother as a Gothic cathedral, this refreshingly offbeat show of 20th-century self-taught artists covers a vivid range of portraits. 5 West 53rd Street (212)265-1040. (Grace Glueck)    * ASIA SOCIETY AND QUEENS MUSEUM OF ART: 'EDGE OF DESIRE: RECENT ART IN INDIA,' through June 5. A highly selective, multigenerational survey of different kinds of contemporary art being made in India; embracing craft, folk and tribal traditions as well as popular culture and academic modernism. The smaller portion is at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 70th Street, (212)288-6400; the more expansive and varied section at the Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718)592-9700. Also at Queens: ''Fatal Love.'' (Holland Cotter)    * BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'BASQUIAT,' through June 5. Jean-Michel Basquiat (1960-88) wrote, painted and drew his way to fame (usually on the same surface) with a loquacious style that mixed mediums and gave visual voice to the glories, history and pain of blackness. Despite a few glitches, this generous retrospective provides an exhilarating account of his short innovative career. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718)638-5000. (Smith)    COOPER-HEWITT NATIONAL DESIGN MUSEUM: 'EXTREME TEXTILES: DESIGNING FOR HIGH PERFORMANCE,' through Oct. 30. Don't look for aesthetic pizazz in this intensely tech-y show of industrial fibers and fabrics; but don't rule it out. The show's raison d'être is solely use, but a lot of what's on view, in the first museum display of material made to function in extreme conditions, is visually exciting. Also at the design museum: ''Hella Jongerius Selects: Works From the Permanent Collection.'' 2 East 91st Street, (212)849-8400. (Glueck)    * EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO: 'MEXICO, THE REVOLUTION AND BEYOND, PHOTOGRAPHS BY CASASOLA 1900-1940,' through July 31. This extraordinary show of work from a photo agency established by Agustín Victor Casasola in Mexico City has the span of a Greek epic and the nested themes and subplots of a picaresque novel, with Revolutionary heroes and a vivid cast of everyday people. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212)831-7272. (Cotter)    SOLOMON R. GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'DANIEL BUREN: THE EYE OF THE STORM,' through June 8. Mr. Buren has devised a lumbering 81-foot-tall construction, mirrored floor to ceiling. Imagine a glass office tower slammed through the front of the building. The spiraling ramps and circular roof complete themselves in the mirrored reflections; there is not much to the work beyond that. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212)423-3500. (Michael Kimmelman)    * SPANISH INSTITUTE: 'FROM GOYA TO SOROLLA,' through July 30. More than 75 pictures from the Hispanic Society, celebrating its centenary; starting with Goya's grave portrait of Pedro Mocarte, they track an arc to figures like Francisco Núñez Losada and salon virtuosi like Ignacio Zuloaga and Joaquín Sorolla. 684 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212)628-0420. (Kimmelman)    INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'LARRY CLARK,' through June 5. The controversial creator of two influential photography books -- ''Tulsa'' (1971) and ''Teenage Lust'' (1983) -- and director of the brilliant movie ''Kids'' (1995) has his first retrospective. The provocative Mr. Clark specializes in the dark and seamy side of American youth culture and his best works are unnervingly intimate, morally disturbing and beautiful. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212)857-0000. (Ken Johnson)    * JAPAN SOCIETY: 'LITTLE BOY: THE ARTS OF JAPAN'S EXPLODING SUBCULTURE,' through July 24. Masterminded by the artist-writer-entrepreneur Takashi Murakami, this eye-boggling show traces the unexamined legacy of World War II as played out in Japan's popular culture. With Godzilla and Hello Kitty presiding, it reveals how this culture was twisted and darkened by the otaku, or geek, subculture, which has in turn influenced younger artists. 333 East 47th Street, (212)832-1155. (Smith)    * METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'DIANE ARBUS REVELATIONS,' through May 30. Arbus could be cruel, but tenderness and melancholy were her finest modes of expression as she captured a moment, the anxious 1950's and 60's, and captured New York. Appropriately, she is given the royal treatment at the Met, including some absurdly theatrical galleries, where her work reveals that in the end we are all drawn together by our different flaws. Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710. (Kimmelman)    METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'THE BISHOP JADES,' through Feb. 12, 2006. Jade has been treasured since ancient time, though the almost preposterously exquisite objects on display in the Met's reinstalled galleries for Chinese decorative arts date from the 18th century, when the Qing dynasty (1644-1911) brought Chinese jade work to a peak of virtuosity. (See above.) (Cotter)    METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'DEFINING YONGLE: IMPERIAL ART IN EARLY 15TH-CENTURY CHINA,' through July 10. Sequestered in the exquisite Chinese decorative arts galleries, this show is both perfect and messy. Its porcelain, metalwork, embroidery and ivory highlight the astounding craftsmanship of the imperial workshops under the Ming emperor Yongle, and reflect the miscegenation of Asian cultures at a time when most roads led to China. (See above.) (Smith)    METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'MAX ERNST: A RETROSPECTIVE,' through July 10. Despite and because of Ernst's being one of modernism's mystery men, he remains of interest, and there are intriguing things in this survey: from early Surrealist paintings, to near-abstract images generated by chance techniques, to the collage-style books some consider his masterworks. But only when he responds to specific events, like war, does his art snap into focus. (See above.) (Cotter)    MUSEUM FOR AFRICAN ART: 'RESONANCE FROM THE PAST,' through May 29. Roughly 90 sculptures, along with a few bead and fabric pieces, from the African holdings of the New Orleans Museum of Art. They make a savory anthology, with plenty of textbook staples, and some surprises. 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718)784-7700. (Cotter)    * MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK: 'EL BARRIO: PUERTO RICAN NEW YORK,' through June 12. A snapshot of El Barrio -- East Harlem, or Spanish Harlem -- as seen through archival images and pictures by the contemporary photographer Hiram S. Maristany taken at a revolutionary political moment in the 1960's and early 70's. 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street, (212)534-1672. (Cotter)    * MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'THOMAS DEMAND,' through May 30. A generally stellar midcareer survey of the 40-year-old German artist, who makes life-size reconstructions of scenes, often ones he has come across in photographs, taking his own cinematic works. 11 West 53rd Street, (212)708-9400. (Kimmelman)    MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'CHRIS MARKER,' through June 13. Made entirely on the computer, ''Owls at Noon Prelude: The Hollow Men'' -- a two-channel, eight-screen DVD with which this French underground film legend makes his New York debut as an installation artist -- gives the horrors of World War I an eroded beauty and haunting pertinence. (See above.) (Smith)    NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN: 'FIRST AMERICAN ART: THE CHARLES AND VALERIE DIKER COLLECTION OF AMERICAN INDIAN ART,' through April 2006. That American Indian art can provide the same aesthetic and emotional pleasure as European and American Modernism is the premise of this show, made up of 200 objects from the Diker Collection, and it affirms American Indian art's worthy aesthetic place in world culture. 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212)514-3700. (Glueck)    NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN: 'GEORGE CATLIN AND HIS INDIAN GALLERY,' through Sept. 5. The portraits and landscapes here give an account of Plains Indian life in the 1830's in wonderful and sometimes harrowing detail. Viewing it is a remarkable experience. (See above.) (Glueck)    NEUE GALERIE: 'PORTRAITS OF AN AGE: PHOTOGRAPHY IN GERMANY AND AUSTRIA, 1900-1938,' through June 6. More than 100 faces shot by 35 photographers. It's a savvy show that homes in on the changing ways people presented themselves in an era of rapidly turning social values. 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212)628-6200. (Glueck)    P.S. 1 CONTEMPORARY ART CENTER: 'GREATER NEW YORK 2005,' through Sept. 26. A youth-besotted, cheerful, immodestly ingratiating, finally disappointing survey of contemporary art, perusing a scene whose wide stylistic range, emphasis on drawing, persistent teenage infatuations and overall dexterousness are firmly entrenched characteristics of the marketplace. 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718)784-2084. (Kimmelman)    * STUDIO MUSEUM IN HARLEM: 'BILL TRAYLOR AND WILLIAM EDMONDSON AND THE MODERNIST IMPULSE,' through July 3. The work of two self-taught proto-modern artists whose beautifully complementary achievements argue against the usual dualities, but offer further evidence that African-American folk art is as great as any art, or music, this country has produced. Also at the museum: ''Chris Ofili: Afro Muses 1995-2005.'' 144 West 125th Street, (212)864-4500. (Smith)    THE UKRAINIAN MUSEUM: 'ALEXANDER ARCHIPENKO: VISION AND CONTINUITY,' through Sept. 4. This rare retrospective of work by the Ukrainian-born sculptor opens the handsome, much-expanded new quarters of this museum. The most exciting part is a beautifully illuminated room of Archipenko's most radical pieces that inspired later artists like Henry Moore. 222 East Sixth Street, East Village, (212)228-0110. (Glueck)    * WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'TIM HAWKINSON,' through May 29. On the gee-whiz meter, Mr. Hawkinson skews high. His midcareer retrospective, like a mad scientists' fair of screwball contraptions, hopscotches from one dexterous tour de force to the next. 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (800)944.8639. (Kimmelman)    WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART AT ALTRIA: 'SUE DE BEER: BLACK SUN,' through June 24. In a walk-in pink castle, ''Black Sun'' is a two-screen video about teenage girlhood, which alternates passages of lyrical visual beauty and emotional poignancy with periods of aimless tedium. 120 Park Avenue at 42nd Street, (917)663-2453. (Johnson)    Galleries: Uptown    * JACK GOLDSTEIN A hero of the Pictures generation revered by the new Pop artists and theorists of the 80's. His films from the early 70's (from 20 seconds to five minutes long) have a cool, deadpan quality recalling early videos of William Wegman. Ed Ruscha-style paintings of lightning storms from the 80's, here and at Metro, are thrillingly cinematic.
